title: The Mental Tug-of-War: Cognitive Dissonance Assessment
description: Explore how you handle contradictions between your values and actions. This research-based assessment identifies patterns in how you resolve mental conflicts and maintain psychological consistency.
author: Dr. N

questions.text: When I make a decision that conflicts with my stated values, I quickly find reasons why it was actually the right choice.
I notice that my opinions about important topics gradually change to align with my recent actions.
When researching a topic, I find myself paying more attention to information that supports what I already believe.
I feel uncomfortable when someone points out inconsistencies between my actions and my stated beliefs.
I sometimes adjust my expressed opinions to match those of people I respect or want to fit in with.
I experience mental tension when I hold two conflicting beliefs or when my actions don't match my values.
I catch myself making excuses for behavior that I would criticize in others.
There are areas where my daily actions don't fully align with my stated values or long-term goals.

bands.label: Low Dissonance
bands.description: You experience minimal cognitive dissonance and have developed effective strategies for maintaining consistency between your values and actions.
bands.advice: Your low dissonance suggests strong self-awareness and value alignment. Consider how you can use this strength to help others navigate their own internal conflicts.

bands.label: Moderate Dissonance
bands.description: You experience typical levels of cognitive dissonance that most people encounter when navigating complex decisions and social situations.
bands.advice: This moderate level is normal and healthy. Focus on developing awareness of when dissonance occurs and practice sitting with the discomfort rather than immediately resolving it.

bands.label: High Dissonance
bands.description: You frequently experience significant mental tension from conflicting beliefs or misaligned actions, which may impact your decision-making and well-being.
bands.advice: Consider exploring the root causes of these conflicts. Sometimes high dissonance indicates areas where personal growth or value clarification could be beneficial.
